title: 110_s1255
content: The Act titled "Indian Arts and Crafts Amendments Act of 2008" amends Section 5 of the Act related to criminal proceedings and civil actions for misrepresentations in Indian arts and crafts. The "Indian Arts and Crafts Amendments Act of 2008" defines a Federal law enforcement officer and grants them authority to investigate violations of the Act within the United States. The Board can refer violations to Federal law enforcement officers for investigation, and officers can investigate without a referral. The Board can refer violations of the "Indian Arts and Crafts Amendments Act of 2008" to Federal law enforcement officers for investigation, regardless of whether they receive a referral. Findings of investigations must be submitted to prosecuting authorities or the Board. The Board may recommend criminal proceedings to the Attorney General and provide support for such actions. The Board can recommend criminal proceedings to the Attorney General and provide support as deemed appropriate. In addition to criminal proceedings, the Board may suggest civil actions under section 6 of the Act. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as 'Indian', 'Indian product', and 'Indian tribe', with specific criteria outlined for each term. The definition of 'Indian tribe' includes formal recognition by the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The curr_chunk discusses the formal recognition of an Indian tribe by a State legislature, commission, or similar organization with recognition authority. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Subsection (b) is amended by changing references from subsection (c) to subsection (d). Subsection (c) is also modified by changing references from subsection (a) to subsection (b) and replacing 'suit' with 'the civil action'. Subsection (d) is repealed. The curr_chunk discusses who may initiate civil actions under subsection (b) of the law, including the Attorney General, Indian tribes, individuals, and Indian arts and crafts organizations. The curr_chunk outlines the disposition of recovered amounts in civil actions under the law, specifying that the recovered amount shall be paid to the Indian tribe, Indian, or Indian arts and crafts organization on whose behalf the action was initiated, with exceptions for deductions by the Attorney General for costs incurred. The recovered amount in civil actions is to be paid to the Indian tribe, Indian, or Indian arts and crafts organization, with deductions allowed by the Attorney General for costs incurred. In civil actions, the Indian tribe can deduct the cost of the action and attorney's fees. In subsection (e), "In the event that" is replaced with "Savings Provision--If". SEC. 3. MISREPRESENTATION OF INDIAN PRODUCED GOODS AND PRODUCTS. Section 1159 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for knowingly violating subsection (a), with fines and imprisonment for individuals and entities selling goods for $1,000 or more. Penalties for violating subsection (a) of Section 1159 of title 18, United States Code, include fines and imprisonment for individuals and entities selling goods for less than $1,000. Repeat violations result in increased fines and longer prison sentences. In subsection (a) of Section 1159 of title 18, United States Code, penalties include fines and imprisonment for up to 15 years for individuals or entities selling goods for less than $1,000. The definition of 'Indian tribe' is clarified to include formally recognized Indian groups by State legislatures, commissions, or similar organizations. The definition of 'Indian tribe' is clarified to include formally recognized Indian groups by State legislatures with tribal recognition authority. The Senate passed the legislation on September 23, 2008, as attested by Secretary Nancy Erickson.
